article.title: A new generation of PARSEC-COLIBRI stellar isochrones including the TP-AGB phase

multiple_choice_question.text: Which type of track includes low-mass stars from the pre-main sequence up to the helium flash at the tip of the red giant branch (RGB)?
choices: HB
INT
TP-AGB
RGB

multiple_choice_question.text: According to the figure, how does the number of thermal pulse cycles (TPCs) generally change with increasing initial mass for a given metallicity?
choices: Stays roughly constant
Increases
Decreases
Shows no clear trend

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main purpose of converting complex TP-AGB tracks into simplified ones containing just the pre-flash quiescent stages?
choices: To speed up the computation of isochrones.
To facilitate interpolation and obtain smoother isochrone sections.
To better represent the detailed physical processes of thermal pulses.
To accurately reproduce the observed luminosities of individual TP-AGB stars.

multiple_choice_question.text: In the top and middle panels, what causes the marked change in the behavior of effective temperature (Teff) along the isochrones?
choices: The transition between the fundamental and first overtone pulsation modes.
The onset of hot-bottom burning (HBB).
The transition from oxygen-rich (O-rich) to carbon-rich (C-rich) stars.
The decrease in stellar mass due to mass loss.

multiple_choice_question.text: What causes the "saturation" of J-Ks colors for the coolest giants with Teff â‰¤ 3000 K?
choices: The change in pulsation mode from fundamental to first overtone.
The formation of large convective cells at the stellar photosphere.
The increasing efficiency of water formation in their atmospheres.
The reprocessing of light by circumstellar dust.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which stellar parameters are used in the formula to predict the pulsation periods of long-period variables (LPVs)?
choices: Mass, radius, effective temperature, metallicity
Mass, radius, envelope mass, chemical type
Luminosity, effective temperature, surface gravity, C/O ratio
Core mass, luminosity, pulsation mode, metallicity

multiple_choice_question.text: According to the figure, at what ages and metallicities are optically-visible C stars most frequent?
choices: Young ages (< 1 Gyr) and high metallicities ([M/H] > 0)
Intermediate ages (1-4 Gyr) and intermediate metallicities (-1 < [M/H] < 0)
Old ages (> 4 Gyr) and low metallicities ([M/H] < -1)
Optically-visible C stars are equally frequent across all ages and metallicities.
